title-group.article-title: Diversity and composition of cave methanotrophic communities

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Methane oxidizing bacteria (methanotrophs) are a ubiquitous group of microorganisms that represent a major sink for the greenhouse gas methane (CH4). Recent studies have demonstrated that methanotrophs are abundant and contribute to CH4 dynamics in caves. However, very little is known about what controls the distribution and abundance of methanotrophs in subterranean ecosystems. Here, we report a survey of sediments collected from >20 caves in North America to elucidate the factors shaping cave methanotroph communities. Using 16S rRNA sequencing, we recovered methanotrophs from nearly all (98 %) of the samples, including cave sites where CH4 concentrations were at or below detection limits (≤ 0.3 ppmv). We identified a core microbiome among caves that was dominated by members of the USC-γ clade, which are recognized as high-affinity methanotrophs. Although methanotrophs were associated with local-scale mineralogy, their community composition did not systematically vary between the entrances and interior of caves, where CH4 concentrations varied. However, we did detect a decay in compositional similarity of methanotrophic community composition with geographic distance. This biogeographic pattern is consistent with dispersal limitation perhaps due to the insular nature of cave ecosystems. Last, the relative abundance of methanotrophs was positively correlated with cave-air CH4 concentrations—suggesting that these microorganisms contribute to CH4 flux in subterranean ecosystems.

sec.title: IMPORTANCE
sec.p: Recent observations have shown that the atmospheric greenhouse gas methane (CH4) is consumed by microorganisms (methanotrophs) in caves at rates comparable to CH4 oxidation in surface soils. Caves are abundant in karst landscapes that comprise 14 % of Earth’s land surface area, and therefore may be acting as a substantial CH4 sink. A detailed ecological understanding of the forces that shape methanotrophic communities in caves is lacking. We sampled cave sediments to better understand the community composition and structure of cave methanotrophs. Our results show that the members of the USC- γ clade are dominant in cave communities, that the relative abundance of methanotrophs was positively correlated with CH4 concentrations in cave air, and that methanotroph relative abundance was correlated with local scale mineralogy of soils.

notes.title: Competing Interest Statement
notes.p: The authors have declared no competing interest.

fn.p: The article has been substantially revised

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Methane (CH4) is a greenhouse gas in Earth’s atmosphere, and an energy source for humanity (1, 2), inspiring research into the sources and sinks of CH4 to and from the atmosphere. Two major processes are responsible for the removal of CH4 from Earth’s atmosphere, oxidation by hydroxyl radicals in the atmosphere, and by methane-consuming microorganisms (methanotrophs) in surface soils. Oxidation by hydroxyl radicals accounts for 90 % of atmospheric-CH4 removal while methanotrophs consume roughly 5 % of the CH4 that is removed from the atmosphere each year (3). Despite the influence that methanotrophs have on regulating Earth’s climate, gaps remain in our understanding of these organisms, like how they respond to changing CH4 concentrations or how they disperse through the environment (4, 5).

Rocks that host caves are widespread on Earth, and are emerging as a global CH4 sink (6–11) (Figure 1), but little is known about the methanotrophic communities in these environments. Recent studies of cave microbial communities have revealed the presence of atmospheric-CH4 consuming or high-affinity methanotrophs in caves (8, 12–15). High-affinity methanotrophs have been previously observed from upland soils and these groups are referred to as the Upland Soil Cluster (USC) -α and -γ clades. Atmospheric CH4 oxidation has also been observed by methanotrophs belonging to the Type II group (organisms in the Methylocystaceae and Beijernickiaceae), but it is not thought that these organisms can consume CH4 at these concentrations indefinitely (16). Both high-affinity and Type II methanotrophs tend to be the most prominent members of the methanotrophic community in environments with low CH4 concentrations and high O2 concentrations. They are less common in environments with high CH4 and low O2 concentrations, like lakes or geological seeps, which are dominated by Type I methanotrophs (methanotrophs from the Methylococcaceae) (17, 18).

caption.p: (A) The distributions of karst landscapes at global scale. Inserts show the occurrence of karst (B) in the eastern United States (C) and in Mexico. Numbers represent the locations of sampled caves in this study. Karst land cover data were obtained from (6, 54).

sec.p: The factors that control the distribution and abundance of methanotrophs in caves are not well understood. Previous work has shown that methanotrophs are frequently related to CH4 concentrations, sediment texture, and other microorganisms, but it is unclear how these factors, or the local mineralogy influences methanotroph communities in caves. Type I and Type II methanotrophs have been shown to exhibit niche partitioning between environments with high and low CH4 concentrations (18, 19). However, it is unknown if methanotrophic communities exhibit similar changes in community composition with atmospheric to subatmospheric CH4 concentration gradients.

In addition, very little is known about the spatial distribution of methanotrophs, even though such information could shed light on the biogeography of microbes within and among cave ecosystems. While the community composition of methanotrophs may be influenced by environmental conditions of caves, their abundances may also be influenced by dispersal limitation. Caves are unique and insular habitats that have a patchy distribution in the terrestrial landscape. Similar methanotrophs have been observed in both Hawai’i and the Arctic (4) suggesting that the dispersal of these organisms is relatively unhindered. However, biota in caves are typically unique due to their isolation from other environments (20, 21). Thus, it may be possible that dispersal limitation is important in structuring the methanotrophic communities in caves. If no group of methanotrophs could consistently be found among caves, this may suggest that methanotrophs are dispersal limited.

In this study, we sampled 21 caves in North America to examine the factors regulating the community composition of cave methanotrophs (Figure 1). First, we hypothesized that the methanotroph community structure should be similar to the structure of methanotrophic communities in other low CH4 environments, and that the relative abundance of methanotrophs should be correlated with cave-air CH4 concentrations.

Additionally, we hypothesized that methanotrophs should show relationships to sediment texture and the minerals present in the environment since these features are known to influence the diffusion of air and micronutrient abundances. Finally, we hypothesized that high-affinity methanotroph communities in caves should exhibit signatures of dispersal-limitation owing to the insular nature of caves.

sec.title: Methanotroph community structure
sec.p: Methanotrophs were recovered in nearly all (98 %) of the cave-sediment samples, including locations where CH4 concentrations were at or below the analytical detection limit (< 0.3 ppmv). The maximum relative abundance of methanotrophs in the cave sediment samples was 6.25 % and the median relative abundance was 0.52 %. The average methanotrophic community contained 3 ± 2 methanotroph OTUs. Methanotrophic communities in the sampled caves were dominated by the USC-γ clade, but members of the USC-α clade, Methylocystaceae, and Methylococcales were also present (Figure 2). Members of the USC clades comprised a median of 99.3 % of the total methanotrophic community at locations where methanotrophs were observed and members of the USC-γ clade represented 70.1 % of the community on average (median). Methanotrophs from the Type II and Type I functional groups represented 0.12 % of the observed methanotroph community on average (median). The observed diversity of the USC-γ and -α clades was lower than that of the Type II and Type I functional groups. Members of the USC-γ and -α were each represented by two unique OTUs, whereas Type II and Type I methanotrophs were represented by seven and 11 unique OTUs respectively.

caption.p: The relative abundance of A) USC methanotrophs, B) Type II methanotrophs, and C) Type I methanotrophs in the sampled caves.

sec.title: Methanotroph core microbiome
sec.p: Taxa that were present in at least 60 % of samples were defined as the core methanotroph community. Based on this definition, the core microbiome was made up of only two OTUs. Both of the OTUs were from members of the USC-γ. These taxa were found together in 84 % of samples, and the most widely distributed OTU was observed in 93 % of samples. The core methanotroph community accounted for 59 % of the obtained methanotroph sequences.

sec.title: Environmental influences on community structure
sec.p: Methanotroph composition was related to the mineralogy of cave soils (Figure 4). The total methanotrophic community was related to the abundance of clinochlorite (p = 0.008), orthoclase (p = 0.006), muscovite (p = 0.05), and microcline (p = 0.04). The USC functional clade showed a relationship with the abundance of clinochlorite (p = 0.02) and the Type II and Type I methanotrophs were not related to the abundance of any observed mineral (p > 0.05). In contrast to mineralogical associations, the composition of the methanotrophic community was not related to soil texture (Table 1).

caption.p: The relative abundance of members of the methanotrophic community plotted against the CH4 concentration at each sample location (ρ = 0.40, S-statistic: S = 5290, p = 0.01).

The total methanotrophic community showed relationships with the abundance of muscovite, clinochlorite, orthoclase, and microcline detected in the samples. The vectors show increasing abundances of minerals the samples.
The p-values associated with the relationship between different methanotrophic communities and soil texture.

sec.title: Biogeography
sec.p: Biological communities are known to change with the geographic distance and the “environmental distance” between them—a pattern known as a distance decay relationship (DDR) (51, 52). At larger spatial scales, methanotrophs showed relationships with measures of geographic distance between the samples. Analysis of methanotroph DDRs revealed that the composition of high-affinity methanotrophs changed faster with respect to geographic than environmental conditions (m High-affinity methanotrophs = −0.14, m environmental conditions = −0.05, p = 0.01) (Figure 5). In contrast, low-affinity methanotroph community composition changed slower than environmental conditions with respect to the geographic distance between the samples (m Low-affinity methanotrophs = 0.10, m environmental conditions = −0.06, p = 0.004). At smaller spatial scales, however, the relative abundance of methanotrophs was not related to the distance from a cave entrance (High-affinity: Spearman’s rank correlations, ρ = −0.05, S = 3854, p = 0.78; Type II: Spearman’s rank correlations, ρ = 0.21, S = 2882, p = 0.28, Type I: Spearman’s rank correlations, ρ = 0.13, S = 2758, p = 0.13).

caption.p: Distance decay analyses of the high affinity. The high-affinity community changed more quickly with changes in geographic distance than changes in environmental conditions. The samples from Cueva de Villa Luz have been removed from this analysis due to the large geographic separation of these samples from the rest of the samples.

sec.title: Relationships with cave air CH4 concentrations
sec.p: The CH4 concentration in cave air was positively correlated with the relative abundance of methanotrophs (Figure 3, Spearman’s Test, ρ = 0.40, S = 5290, p = 0.01). This relationship was largely driven by the USC functional groups (Spearman’s Test, ρ = 0.40, S = 5887, p = 0.01). The relative abundances of Type II and Type I methanotrophs were not correlated with the CH4 concentration (Type II: Spearman’s rank correlations, ρ = 0.04, S = 9462, p = 0.79; Type I: Spearman’s rank correlations, ρ = −0.01, S = 10002, p = 0.94).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The process of life is fundamentally centered on obtaining energy from the surrounding environment and methanotrophs are no exception. As such, methanotrophic clades avoid competition with each other by partitioning the ranges across which they consume CH4. USC clades rely on CH4 concentrations that are at or near atmospheric levels, whereas Type II methanotrophs may only survive and metabolize atmospheric CH4 for a limited time period under such conditions, while Type I methanotrophs are thought to be unable to persist in environments with atmospheric CH4 concentrations (22–24). While energy availability is crucial, life is also dependent on the supply of specific nutrients and micronutrients for biosynthetic processes. Our findings support these universal requirements based on patterns of methanotrophic diversity in caves.

sec.title: Methanotroph α- and β-diversity in caves
sec.p: Methanotrophs are widespread in cave environments. The dominance of the high-affinity methanotrophs from the USC clades in the sampled caves is consistent with observations that have been made in other low CH4 environments. For example, high-affinity taxa dominate methanotroph assemblages in forest soils, Arctic soils, and soils associated with basaltic rocks (4, 25, 26). Additionally, the high relative abundance of methanotrophs in the sampled cave sediments from this study, and in particular of the USC-γ clade, agrees with observations of high relative abundances of USC methanotrophs from 2 to 12 % in other caves (8, 12, 14, 15). The high relative abundances of methanotrophs observed in our study are higher than the observations of methanotrophs from caves in Vietnam (7) and contrasts with the relatively depauperate assemblage found in a Spanish cave, which reportedly consisted of only three species (27)

Although less abundant, Type II and Type I methanotrophs were also commonly observed from our cave survey. Type II methanotrophs are typically more abundant in aerated soils with access to oxygen and Type I methanotrophs are typically observed in environments with high CH4 concentrations and low oxygen availability (17, 18). Cave soils are typically nutrient poor (28, 29), implying that anoxic conditions created by the decay of organic matter are not likely to be widespread. Thus, their presence in cave soils may be limited to local pockets of anoxia which have been suggested based on observations of limited methanogenesis in cave systems (10, 11).

We identified a core group of two OTUs that were present in the studied caves. The core methanotrophic community was derived entirely of members from the USC-γ clade. This suggests these methanotrophs are well attuned to cave environments and may be able to disperse between them easily. The fact that these methanotrophs accounted for 59 % of the observed methanotrophs suggests these organisms are reproducing in these environments as well. Previous observations are also indicative of high-dispersal capabilities for these organisms. For example, methanotrophs from a newly formed soil in Hawai’i showed close taxonomic affiliations with Arctic methanotrophs (4). Additionally, microbes are known to travel intercontinental distances on windblown dust (30), and perhaps windblown dust may carry methanotrophs into caves.

sec.title: Microenvironmental influences on methanotroph communities
sec.p: The relationship between the mineralogical assemblage and methanotrophs at the sample sites is probably related to the abundance of trace metals. Copper is the trace metal responsible for the oxidation of CH4 in particulate methane monooxygenase enzyme of methanotrophs. The methanotroph community showed relationships with the abundance of clinochlorite, orthoclase, muscovite, and microcline. These minerals are associated with felsic metamorphic and igneous rocks, and metals like copper are associated with these kinds of rocks (31).

In contrast, the grain size of the cave sediments did not influence the methanotroph community composition nor their abundance, even though it reflects important physical and chemical properties. Previous research observed that methanotrophs tend to be more abundant in silt and clay fractions of soils because these fractions made up the bulk of the soils themselves, and potentially that these soils may have greater organic matter contents (32, 33). The lack of relationships between methanotroph community composition and methanotroph abundance agree with previous studies where no relationship was observed between these variables (34).

sec.title: Biogeography of methanotroph communities
sec.p: Methanotrophic communities showed relationships with regional assessments of geographic distance, but did not show relationships with local assessments. The community composition of high affinity methanotrophs changed faster than the environmental variables. This suggests that process like community sorting are operating on this community (35). If community sorting is operating on high-affinity methanotrophs, they may be actively adjusting to the cave environment and preventing the establishment of other groups of organisms in this environment. Conversely, the slope of the community composition of both Type II and Type I (low affinity) methanotrophs, changed more slowly than the slope variables comprising environmental similarity when compared to changes in the geographic distance. This suggests that neutral processes are operating on these communities (35). These processes are thought to operate more strongly on communities that are not strongly influenced by the environment and are the strongest in small populations (36). This suggests that these communities may be being passively dispersed into the caves or awaiting favorable conditions to carryout active metabolism.

The composition and abundance of methanotrophic communities close to cave entrances was not different compared to those in more interior locations. The most probable explanation for this is that the distance from a cave entrance is a proxy variable for how interior a specific point is in a cave, but is not an absolute variable. Cave size and shape may prevent the distance from a cave entrance from being a useful variable for predicting cave methanotrophic community composition.

sec.title: Relationships with cave air CH4 concentrations
sec.p: The relative abundance of methanotrophs was positively correlated with CH4 concentrations in cave air. This pattern was driven by the high-affinity methanotrophs. High-affinity methanotrophs are thought to derive a significant portion of their energy from CH4 at atmospheric concentrations and less energy is available for these organisms at locations in caves with sub-atmospheric CH4 concentrations. Some of the variability observed in the relationship between high-affinity methanotrophs and cave air CH4 concentrations may be explained by daily and seasonal variation in cave air flow patterns. Many caves are known to exhibit faster air flow when the external atmospheric temperature is lower than the temperature of cave air. This leads to higher CH4 concentrations in caves during the winter (10, 37). Our samples were acquired during summer, so it is likely that the CH4 concentration observed at the sample sites may fluctuate around our observations.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The structure of cave methanotroph communities appears to be best understood in terms of how cave methanotrophs access CH4. Cave methanotrophic communities showed relationships with cave-air CH4 concentrations suggesting these communities are actively consuming CH4 within the cave environment. Additionally, methanotroph communities showed relationships to minerals in the environment that are known to be related to the abundance of Cu, an essential trace metal for methane oxidation. Methanotrophs from the USC-γ clade were numerically dominant. This community structure mirrors that of other cave communities (8, 12, 14, 15). Members from this clade also comprised a core methanotrophic community with both members present together in 84 % of samples. The cave methanotrophic community assemblage appears to be undergoing the effects of community sorting and does not appear to be dispersal limited. This result also suggests that the dispersal barrier for high-affinity methanotrophs from cave to cave may be low.

sec.title: Microbial sampling
sec.p: We sampled microbial communities from caves along the western front of the Appalachian fold and thrust belt, in intracratonic settings of the USA, and in the Sierra Madre of Mexico. We obtained 42 sediment samples from the caves along transects from their entrances to interiors. Cave sediment samples from walls and floors were collected using a spatula that had been sterilized with 70 volume % ethanol in water from locations that were 0.1 m2 in area (38). Samples were stored on ice until they could be transferred to a −80 °C freezer.

sec.title: Environmental variables
sec.p: We measured multiple environmental variables to assess factors that potentially influence the composition of cave methanotrophic communities. We measured CH4 concentrations in-situ with Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) (Gasmet DX4030 – Milton Keynes, United Kingdom) or we collected discrete air samples collected in the field for measurement the laboratory with FTIR spectroscopy or gas-chromatography (Varian – Agilent Technologies, Palo Alto, California). Some of the CH4 concentrations listed in this study have been previously published (11, 39), and new data were collected according to methods reported in the same publications. In cases where cave maps were available, the distance from the nearest entrance to the sampling location was calculated along the length of the cave passages. We measured cave sediment grain-size distributions with a Malvern Mastersizer 3000 (Malvern Instruments Inc., Westborough Massachusetts). Raw data from the Mastersizer were converted to % gravel, % sand, % silt, and % clay sized particles by volume using the GRADISTAT software package (40). Metadata used for statistical analyses are available in a public GitHub repository (https://github.com/websterkgd/CaveMethanotrophs)

sec.title: Cave sediment mineralogy
sec.p: We randomly selected 14 samples for mineralogical analysis using X-ray powder diffraction. Sediments were powdered to < 5 μm using a mortar, pestle, and acetylene. Following the methods of Furmann et al. (41), we used Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with a Sol-X solid-state detector and a W X-ray tube operated at 30 mA and 40 kV to identify mineral phases. We placed cave sediment powders in an aluminum large frontpacked mount. Packed mounts were scanned from 2° to 70° using a count time of 2 s per 0.02° step. Rietveld refinements were used to determine the abundances of the minerals present in the sample and were quantified with TOPAS software.

sec.title: Molecular techniques
sec.p: We extracted Genomic DNA from cave sediment samples with a MoBio PowerSoilTM extraction kit (MoBio, Carlsbad, California USA). About 10 ng of extracted DNA was used as a template for amplification by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). The V4 region of the 16S rRNA gene was amplified using 515F and 806R with barcoded primers designed to work with the Illumina MiSeq platform (42). DNAamplification was performed using 50 μL reactions from each sample. PCR reactions were carried out by a 3 min denaturing step at 94 °C, followed by 30 cycles of 94 °C for 45 s, 50 °C for 60 s, and 72 °C for 90 s. A final 10-minute extension was carried out at 72 °C. Quality of the PCR amplifications was checked by gel electrophoresis. Amplified DNA was cleaned using a commercial kit (Beckman Coulter Agencourt AMPure XP, Indianapolis, Indiana, USA). Once the DNA was cleaned, the DNA concentrations were quantified using the QuanIt PicoGreen kit (Invitrogen) and were pooled at a final concentration of 20 ng per sample.

We sequenced the cleaned PCR amplicons using Illumina MiSeq technology (Illumina Reagent Kit v2, 500 reaction kit) at the Center for Bioinformatics and Genomics at Indiana University. Data quality and unique sequences obtained from the PCR amplifications were analyzed using mothur (43). DNA sequence data were aligned using the Needleman algorithm and read lengths were limited to 197 base pairs. Sequences matching chimeras were removed using VSEARCH (44). Sequences that matched chloroplasts, Archaea, and other non-bacterial sequences were also removed. OTUs were created by binning the data at 97 % sequence similarity using the opticlust algorithm (45). OTUs were identified using the SILVA reference database (version 132).

sec.title: Identification of methanotrophs
sec.p: We identified methanotrophs from the 16S rRNA sequences using a three step process. First, we compiled a database of organisms known methanotrophs through literature surveys. Type I MOB were classified as the known methanotrophic members of the Methylococcaceae. We defined Type II MOB as known methanotrophic genera in the Methylocystaceae and Beijernickiaceae (23, 24). We used the genera Methylacidiphilum, Methylacidimicrobium to identify methanotrophs belonging to the Verrucomicrobia (24, 46). High-affinity MOB were defined as organisms belonging to the USC-α and -γ clades (13, 23, 24). 16S rRNA sequences for USC-α and USC-γ MOB were obtained using published 16S rRNA sequences for USC-α from (12) and for USC-γ from (13). Second, organisms from this database were checked against the identifications assigned to the OTUs during the initial analysis from the SILVA database. Third, we compiled a FASTA file of the 16S rRNA gene of these organisms and this file was compared against the FASTA file of all organisms in the dataset using the usearch_global command to identify putative methanotrophs that may have been missed through the SILVA analysis (usearch v.11.0.667) (47). This list of putative methanotophs was then compared against the NCBI database. If the sequences did not match an organism capable of the function of interest at 98 % similarity they were excluded from downstream analysis. The compiled methanotroph FASTA file used in our analysis is available in a public GitHub repository (https://github.com/websterkgd/CaveMethanotrophs).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: We assessed the relationships between methanotrophs and environmental conditions through a series of statistical analyses. First, to avoid complication arising from unavoidable variation in the total number of reads between samples, we calculated the relative abundance for each taxon within a sample. Next, to quantify among cave variation, we calculated pairwise dissimilarities using the Bray-Curtis metric. The methanotroph core microbiome was characterized by including taxa that were found in 60 % or more of our samples. We used this cutoff because it is in the middle of the range of what has been used in other studies (48, 49). We evaluated the effect of sediment mineralogy and grain size on the multivariate composition of methanotroph communities using canonical correspondence analysis (CCA) with the vegan package in R (50).

To gain insight into the biogeography of cave methanotrophs, we constructed a DDR while also comparing community composition along gradients from cave exteriors to cave interiors. We analyzed DDR using Bray-Curtis measures of community similarity and Euclidian measures of environmental similarity that had been scaled from 0 to 1. Samples from Cave 38 (Cueva de Villa Luz) were excluded in DDR analyses since they were roughly 2000 km away from the nearest sample. Slopes for geographic and environmental DDR were calculated using ordinary least squares (52). We then tested for differences in the slopes using the diffslope() function R package simba, which calculates statistical significance through a permutation-based linear regression approach (53). We used Spearman’s correlation to examine how methanotrophic communities changed along gradients from cave exteriors to interiors. Finally, we tested for a relationship between methanotroph relative abundance and CH4 concentrations using Spearman’s correlation.

sec.title: Data and software availability
sec.p: This Targeted Locus Study project has been deposited at DDBJ/EMBL/GenBank under the accession KCRG00000000. The version described in this paper is the first version, KCRG00000000.1. All code and data used in this study can be found in a public GitHub repository (https://github.com/websterkgd/CaveMethanotrophs).

Additional support was provided by a National Speleological Society research grant awarded to KDW, the National Geographic Society Expeditions Council (Grant #EC0644-13 to PJB), the National Science Foundation (1442246 to JTL), the US Army Research Office (W911NF-14-1-0411 to JTL) and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (80NSSC20K0618 to JTL). We thank Brent Lehmkuhl for assistance in the laboratory. Members of the Bloomington Indiana Grotto facilitated access to caves in Indiana and Kentucky. We thank Rodolfo Gómez Cruz for his support at Cueva de Villa Luz (Cave 38). ML Larsen, MM Muscarella, and KJ Locey aided in data analysis and interpretation. KDW thanks the Planetary Science Institute Mars Laboratory for providing computing resources. The authors declare no conflicts of interest. Finally, KDW would like to thank Cato the Elder and Scipio Aemilianus for advocating for the destruction of Carthage.
